From Jonathan Harker's Journal, October 4th: After reading Van Helsing's phonograph message to Mina, my poor wife seemed much brighter. The certainty that Count Dracula is no longer in England has brought her comfort, which in turn gives her strength. For my part, with the immediate, horrific threat gone, it feels almost unbelievable it ever happened. Even the terrifying experiences I had at Castle Dracula now seem like a distant, forgotten dream, especially here in the crisp autumn air and bright sunshine. Alas, how can I doubt? As I was thinking this, my eyes fell upon the red scar on my poor darling's white forehead. As long as that mark is there, I cannot possibly doubt. And even when it's gone, its memory will keep my faith perfectly clear. Mina and I are afraid to be idle, so we've been going over all the diaries repeatedly. Strangely, while the reality of the situation feels more significant each time, the pain and fear seem to lessen. There appears to be some guiding purpose running through everything, which is comforting. Mina believes perhaps we are instruments meant for ultimate good. It could be! I will try to adopt her perspective. We haven't discussed the future with each other yet. It seems best to wait until we meet with the Professor and the others after they finish their investigations. This day is passing more quickly than I ever thought a day could for me again. It's already three o'clock.

Mina Harker's Journal, October 5th, 5 p.m.: We held a meeting to report on our findings. Those present were Professor Van Helsing, Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, Mr. Quincey Morris, Jonathan Harker, and myself, Mina Harker.

Dr. Van Helsing explained the steps they took today to figure out which boat Count Dracula escaped on and where it was headed:

"Since I knew he wanted to return to Transylvania," Van Helsing began, "I was certain he would travel via the mouth of the Danube or somewhere else on the Black Sea, as that's how he arrived. It was a discouraging blank start for us. 'Omne ignotum pro magnifico' (Everything unknown is taken for something grand); so with heavy hearts, we began looking for ships that sailed for the Black Sea last night. He was on a sailing ship, as Madam Mina mentioned sails being set. These smaller ships often aren't listed prominently like the big ones in the Times' shipping report, so, following Lord Godalming's suggestion, we went to your Lloyd's, where records of all sailing vessels, no matter how small, are kept. There we found that only one ship bound for the Black Sea left with the tide. She is named the Czarina Catherine, sailing from Doolittle's Wharf towards Varna, and from there continuing to other places and up the Danube. 'Aha!' I said, 'This must be the ship carrying the Count.' So we immediately went to Doolittle's Wharf. There we found a man in a tiny wooden office, so small that the man looked larger than his workspace. We asked him about the Czarina Catherine's departure. He swore a lot, was red-faced, and loud, but he was a decent fellow nonetheless. And when Quincey discreetly gave him some crackling paper from his pocket, which the man quickly rolled up and hid in a small bag deep within his clothes, he became an even better fellow and was eager to help us. He came with us and questioned many rough, sweaty men working there; these men also became more cooperative once their thirst was quenched. They used many terms involving 'blood' and 'bloom' and other words I didn't understand, though I could guess their meaning; but despite that, they told us everything we needed to know.

"They collectively informed us how, yesterday afternoon around five o'clock, a man arrived in a great hurry. He was tall, thin, and pale, with a high nose, very white teeth, and eyes that seemed to burn. He wore all black, except for a straw hat that didn't suit him or the season. He scattered money around while quickly asking about ships sailing for the Black Sea and their destinations. Some people took him to the office and then towards the ship, but he didn't go aboard. Instead, he stopped at the shore end of the gang-plank and asked for the captain to come to him. The captain came when told he would be paid well; and although he swore profusely at first, he agreed to the terms. Then the thin man left, and someone directed him to a place where he could hire a horse and cart. He went there and soon returned, driving the cart himself, carrying a large box. He lifted this box down himself, though it took several others to lift it onto the ship's truck. He spoke extensively with the captain about how and where his box should be placed, but the captain didn't like it and swore at him in many languages, telling him he could come aboard and see where it was put if he wished. But he said 'no', that he wouldn't come just yet as he had much to do. Whereupon the captain told him he'd better hurry—'with blood'—because his ship would leave the 'place—of blood'—before the tide turned—'with blood'. Then the thin man smiled and said that of course, the ship would leave when the captain thought fit, but he would be surprised if it departed quite so soon. The captain swore again, in many languages, and the thin man bowed, thanked him, and said he would 'intrude' on his kindness by coming aboard before sailing. Finally, the captain, redder than ever and using even more languages, told him he didn't want any 'Frenchmen—with bloom upon them and also with blood—in his ship—with blood on her also'. And so, after asking where he might buy ship forms nearby, he left.

"No one knew where he went or 'bloomin' well cared,' as they put it, because they soon had other things to worry about—'well with blood again.' For it quickly became clear to everyone that the Czarina Catherine wouldn't sail as planned. A thin mist began to creep up from the river, and it grew and grew until a dense fog enveloped the ship and everything around her. The captain swore in multiple languages—very polyglot, polyglot with bloom and blood—but he could do nothing. The water level rose, and he began to fear he would miss the high tide entirely. He was in a very bad mood when, just at full tide, the thin man came back up the gang-plank and asked to see where his box had been stored. The captain replied that he wished both the man and his box—'old and with much bloom and blood'—were in hell. But the thin man wasn't offended. He went down with the mate, saw where it was placed, came back up, and stood on deck for a while in the fog. He must have gotten off by himself, as no one noticed him leave. Indeed, they weren't thinking about him, because soon after, the fog began to disappear, and everything was clear again. My thirsty friends with their colorful language laughed as they recounted how the captain's swearing surpassed even his usual multi-lingual outbursts, becoming even more vivid when he questioned other sailors on the river that hour and found that few of them had seen any fog at all, except right around the wharf. Nevertheless, the ship sailed out on the ebb tide and was undoubtedly far down the river mouth by morning. By the time they told us this, she was well out at sea.

"And so, my dear Madam Mina," Van Helsing concluded, "we must pause for now, for our enemy is at sea, with the fog at his command, heading towards the Danube mouth. Sailing takes time, no matter how fast the ship; but when we start, we can travel overland much faster and intercept him there. Our best hope is to find him when he is in his box between sunrise and sunset, for then he is helpless, and we can deal with him as we should. We have several days to prepare our plan. We know exactly where he is going, as we have seen the ship's owner, who showed us the invoices and all the necessary documents. The box we seek is to be unloaded in Varna and handed over to an agent named Ristics, who will present his credentials there. So our merchant friend will have completed his part. When he asked if anything was wrong, suggesting he could telegraph Varna and have inquiries made, we said 'no,' because what needs to be done is not a matter for the police or customs. It must be handled by us alone, in our own way."

After Dr. Van Helsing finished speaking, I asked him if he was absolutely certain that the Count had stayed on board the ship. He replied, "We have the best proof: your own testimony from your hypnotic trance this morning." I asked him again if it was truly necessary to pursue the Count, for I dread Jonathan leaving me, knowing he would certainly go if the others did. He answered with increasing intensity, starting quietly but growing more angry and forceful as he spoke, until we could clearly see at least some of that personal dominance that had made him a leader among men for so long:

"Yes, it is necessary—absolutely necessary! First for your sake, and then for the sake of all humanity. This monster has already caused immense harm within the limited sphere where he operated and during the short time he was here, when he was still like a body groping blindly in darkness, not fully knowing his own small power. I have told the others all this; you, my dear Madam Mina, will hear it on my friend John's phonograph or your husband's. I have explained to them how the enormous task of leaving his own barren land—empty of people—and coming to a new country teeming with life, like a multitude of standing corn, was the result of centuries of work. If another of the Un-Dead, like him, were to attempt what he has done, perhaps all the centuries that have passed or ever will pass wouldn't help him. With this one, all the deep, strong, hidden forces of nature must have combined in some miraculous way. The very place where he has lived as Un-Dead for centuries is full of strange geological and chemical phenomena. There are deep caverns and fissures leading nobody knows where. There have been volcanoes, some still emitting waters with bizarre properties and gases that can kill or revitalize. Doubtless, there is something magnetic or electric in some of these combinations of occult forces that strange ways nourish physical life; and he himself possessed great qualities from the beginning. In a difficult, warlike era, he was renowned for having more courage, a more cunning mind, and a braver heart than anyone else. In him, some vital principle found its ultimate expression in a strange way; and as his body remained strong and grew, his brain grew too. All this happened without needing that diabolic assistance, which surely belongs to him; for it must ultimately yield to the powers that come from and symbolize good. And now this is what he means to us. He has infected you—oh, forgive me, my dear, for having to say such a thing; but I speak for your own good. He infected you in such a way that even if he does nothing more, you only have to live—to live in your own familiar, sweet way; and so in time, death, which is the common lot of man and sanctioned by God, will make you like him. This must not happen! We have sworn together that it will not. Thus we serve God's own will: that the world, and the men for whom His Son died, will not be surrendered to monsters whose very existence would dishonor Him. He has already allowed us to save one soul, and we go forth like the knights of the Cross in old times to save more. Like them, we shall travel towards the sunrise; and like them, if we fall, we fall in a righteous cause." He paused, and I said:

"But won't the Count wisely accept this setback? Since he's been driven from England, won't he avoid it, like a tiger avoids the village from which he's been hunted?"

"Aha!" he exclaimed, "your comparison to the tiger is excellent for me, and I will use it. Your man-eater, as they call the tiger in India that has tasted human blood, cares no more for other prey but prowls incessantly until he gets it. This creature we are hunting from our village is also a tiger, a man-eater, and he will never stop prowling. No, by his very nature, he is not one to retreat and stay away. In his living life, he crossed the Turkish frontier and attacked his enemy on their own territory; he was beaten back, but did he stay away? No! He came back, again and again. Look at his persistence and endurance. With the undeveloped mind he had long ago, he conceived the idea of coming to a great city. What did he do? He found the most promising place in the entire world for his purposes. Then he deliberately and patiently set about preparing for the task. He discovered his strengths and powers through careful patience. He studied new languages. He learned about new social life, the new environment of old ways, politics, law, finance, science, the customs of a new land and people who have come into being since his time. The brief glimpse he had here only sharpened his appetite and intensified his desire. No, it even helped his brain grow, because it proved to him how absolutely right his initial hunches were. He accomplished all this alone, entirely alone! Starting from a ruined tomb in a forgotten land. What more might he not do now that the wider world of thought is open to him? He is someone who can smile at death, as we understand it; who can flourish amidst diseases that wipe out entire populations. Oh, if such a being were to come from God, not the Devil, what a force for good he might be in this old world of ours! But we are committed to setting the world free. Our work must be silent, and our efforts entirely secret, for in this enlightened age, when men doubt even what they see, the skepticism of wise men would be his greatest strength. It would serve as both his shield and his armor, and his weapons to destroy us, his enemies, who are willing to risk even our own souls for the safety of someone we love—for the good of humanity, and for the honor and glory of God."

Following a general discussion, it was decided that nothing definite would be settled for tonight; we should all consider the facts and try to arrive at the proper conclusions. Tomorrow morning, at breakfast, we will meet again, share our conclusions with one another, and then decide on a specific course of action.

.......................

I feel a wonderful sense of peace and rest tonight. It's as if some lingering presence has been removed from me. Perhaps...

My thought was interrupted; I couldn't finish it. I caught sight of the red mark on my forehead in the mirror and knew I was still tainted.

Dr. Seward's Diary, October 5th: We all woke up early, and I believe sleep greatly benefited each of us. When we met for an early breakfast, there was more general cheerfulness than any of us had expected to experience again.

It's truly amazing how much resilience human nature possesses. Remove any obstacle, no matter what, by any means—even death—and we quickly revert to our fundamental principles of hope and enjoyment. More than once as we sat around the table, my eyes widened in wonder, questioning if the entire past few days hadn't been a dream. It was only when I saw the red mark on Mrs. Harker's forehead that I was pulled back to reality. Even now, as I seriously ponder the matter, it seems almost impossible to grasp that the source of all our troubles still exists. Even Mrs. Harker seems to lose sight of her ordeal for periods; it's only occasionally, when something reminds her, that she thinks of her terrible scar. We are scheduled to meet in my study in half an hour to decide on our course of action. I see only one immediate problem, which I sense instinctively rather than rationally: we must all speak honestly, yet I fear that in some mysterious way, poor Mrs. Harker's ability to speak freely is hindered. I know she forms her own conclusions, and from everything that has happened, I can guess how insightful and accurate they must be; but she is unwilling, or unable, to express them. I've mentioned this to Van Helsing, and he and I are going to discuss it when we are alone. I assume this is some effect of that dreadful 'poison' that entered her veins starting to work. The Count had his own reasons when he gave her what Van Helsing called 'the Vampire's baptism of blood.' Well, perhaps a poison can even be derived from good things; in an age when the very existence of ptomaines is still debated, we shouldn't be surprised by anything! One thing I know for sure: if my intuition about poor Mrs. Harker's silence is correct, then there is a terrible difficulty—an unknown danger—in the task ahead. The same power that forces her silence might also force her to speak (to the Count). I dare not think further, for doing so would dishonor a noble woman in my thoughts!

Van Helsing is coming to my study a little before the others. I will try to introduce the topic with him.

Later: When the Professor arrived, we discussed the situation. I could see he had something on his mind he wanted to say but felt hesitant to bring it up. After some beating around the bush, he suddenly said, "Friend John, there is something you and I must discuss alone, at least at first. Later, we may have to share it with the others." Then he stopped, so I waited; he continued:

"Madam Mina, our poor, dear Madam Mina is changing." A cold shiver went through me, confirming my worst fears. Van Helsing went on: "Given the sad experience with Miss Lucy, we must be forewarned this time before things go too far. Our task is now actually more difficult than ever, and this new problem makes every hour critically important. I can see the signs of the vampire starting to appear in her face. It is very, very subtle now, but it can be seen if one looks carefully without prejudice. Her teeth are a little sharper, and sometimes her eyes are harder. But these aren't the only signs; she is often silent now, just as Miss Lucy was. Lucy didn't speak, even when she wrote down what she wanted known later. Now, my fear is this: If she can, through our hypnotic trance, reveal what the Count sees and hears, isn't it more likely that he who first hypnotized her, and who drank her blood and made her drink his, could, if he wished, compel her mind to reveal to him what she knows?" I nodded in agreement; he continued:

"Then, what we must do is prevent this. We must keep her unaware of our intentions, so she cannot reveal what she doesn't know. This is a painful task! Oh, so painful that it breaks my heart to think of; but it must be done. When we meet today, I must tell her that for reasons we cannot disclose, she must no longer be part of our discussions but simply be protected by us." He wiped his forehead, which was covered in sweat at the thought of the pain he might have to inflict on the poor soul who was already so tormented. I knew it would bring him some comfort if I told him I had reached the same conclusion; at least it would remove the pain of doubt. I told him, and the effect was exactly as I expected.

It is now almost time for our general meeting. Van Helsing has left to prepare for the meeting and his difficult role in it. I truly believe he wants time to pray alone.

Later: At the very beginning of our meeting, both Van Helsing and I felt a great personal relief. Mrs. Harker had sent a message through her husband saying she would not join us for now, as she thought it better that we be free to discuss our plans without her presence causing any constraint. The Professor and I exchanged a look for an instant, and somehow, we both felt relieved. For my part, I thought that if Mrs. Harker herself recognized the danger, it averted a great deal of both pain and danger. Under the circumstances, we agreed, with a questioning look and a silent answer (finger on lip), to keep our suspicions quiet until we could speak alone again. We immediately launched into planning our campaign. Van Helsing first briefly presented the facts:

"The Czarina Catherine left the Thames yesterday morning. At the fastest speed she can manage, it will take her at least three weeks to reach Varna; but we can travel overland to the same place in three days. Now, if we subtract two days from the ship's voyage time, allowing for such weather influences as we know the Count can exert; and if we allow a full day and night for any delays we might encounter, then we have a margin of nearly two weeks. Thus, to be completely safe, we must leave here by the 17th at the very latest. Then we will definitely be in Varna a day before the ship arrives and able to make any necessary preparations. Of course, we will all go armed—armed against evil things, both spiritual and physical." Here Quincey Morris added:

"I understand the Count comes from a region with many wolves, and it's possible he might get there overland faster than the ship. I suggest we add Winchesters to our weapons. I have a certain faith in a Winchester when facing trouble of that kind. Do you remember, Art, when we were chased by the wolf pack at Tobolsk? What wouldn't we have given for a repeater each then!"

"Excellent!" said Van Helsing, "Winchesters it shall be. Quincey's judgment is always sound, but especially so when it comes to hunting. The metaphor dishonors science less than wolves endanger man. In the meantime, there is nothing we can do here; and since I believe Varna is unfamiliar to all of us, why not go there sooner? Waiting here is as long as waiting there. Tonight and tomorrow we can get ready, and then, if all goes well, we four can begin our journey."

"We four?" Harker asked, looking questioningly from one of us to another.

"Of course!" the Professor answered quickly, "you must remain to take care of your dear wife!" Harker was silent for a moment and then said in a strained voice, "Let us discuss that part of it in the morning. I want to consult with Mina." I thought this was the moment for Van Helsing to warn him not to reveal our plans to her; but he showed no sign. I looked at him meaningfully and coughed. In response, he put his finger to his lips and turned away.

Jonathan Harker's Journal, October 5th, afternoon: For some time after our meeting this morning, I was unable to think. The new developments have left my mind in a state of shock that prevents any active thought. Mina's decision not to participate in the discussion made me think; and since I couldn't argue with her about it, I could only speculate. I am still as far as ever from understanding it. The way the others accepted it also confused me; the last time we discussed the subject, we agreed there would be no more secrets among us. Mina is sleeping now, peacefully and sweetly like a small child. Her lips are curved, and her face is radiant with happiness. Thank God that she can still have such moments.

Later: How strange it all is. I sat watching Mina sleep happily and felt as close to being happy myself as I suppose I ever will be. As evening approached and the earth cast shadows from the setting sun, the silence in the room felt more and more solemn to me. Suddenly, Mina opened her eyes and, looking at me with great tenderness, said, "Jonathan, I want you to make me a promise on your word of honor. A promise made to me, but made sacredly before God, and not to be broken, even if I were to fall on my knees and beg you with bitter tears. Quickly, you must make it to me at once."

"Mina," I said, "a promise like that, I cannot make immediately. I may not have the right to make it."

"But, my dear one," she said, with such spiritual intensity that her eyes seemed like guiding stars, "it is I who wish it; and it is not for my own sake. You can ask Dr. Van Helsing if I am right; if he disagrees, you are free to do as you will. Furthermore, if you all agree later, you are released from the promise." 

"I promise!" I said, and for a moment, she looked perfectly happy; though to me, all her happiness was overshadowed by the red scar on her forehead. She said:

"Promise me that you will not tell me anything about the plans made for the campaign against the Count. Not by word, or hint, or suggestion; never, as long as this mark remains upon me!" and she solemnly pointed to the scar. I saw that she was serious and said solemnly, "I promise!" and as I said it, I felt that from that instant, a barrier had been erected between us.

Later, midnight: Mina has been bright and cheerful throughout the evening. So much so that everyone else seemed to gain courage, as if catching some of her gaiety; as a result, even I felt as though the cloud of gloom weighing us down had lifted somewhat. We all went to bed early. Mina is now sleeping like a small child; it is a wonderful thing that she can still sleep amidst her terrible troubles. Thank God for that, for then at least she can forget her worries. Perhaps her example of sleep will affect me as her cheerfulness did tonight. I will try it. Oh, for a sleep without dreams.

events.title: Mina's Adamant Demand to Join the Dangerous Expedition
detailed_summary: On the morning of October 6th, Mina awakens Jonathan early, asking him to fetch Dr. Van Helsing.
Jonathan, assuming it's for another hypnotic session, complies without question and finds the Professor already dressed and expecting a summons, his door ajar.
As Van Helsing enters their room, he asks Mina if the other men should join them.
Mina simply replies that it won't be necessary and that Van Helsing can relay the information to them: she declares she must accompany them on their journey.
Both Van Helsing and Jonathan are taken aback by her statement.
Van Helsing, after a pause, asks for her reasoning.
Mina explains that she is safer with them, and they, in turn, will be safer with her.
Van Helsing, though acknowledging their duty to ensure her safety, points out the dangers they face, to which she might be more susceptible due to her circumstances, pausing awkwardly.
Mina, pointing to the scar on her forehead, affirms her awareness of this and states it is precisely why she must go.
She explains that she can speak freely now, as the sun is rising, but might not be able to later, knowing that when the Count wills it, she must obey, even if it means deceiving Jonathan.
Jonathan is deeply moved by the look she gives him as she says this.
Mina further argues that while the men are brave and strong in their numbers, she can be of service through hypnosis, allowing them to learn things even she is unaware of.
Dr. Van Helsing gravely acknowledges Mina's wisdom and agrees that she shall accompany them, and together they will achieve their goal.
After he speaks, Mina falls back onto her pillow asleep, so deeply that she doesn't wake even when Jonathan lets in bright sunlight.
Van Helsing motions Jonathan to follow him quietly to his room, where they are quickly joined by Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris.
Van Helsing relays what Mina said, emphasizing the new factor of her participation, praising her true soul despite the agony her revelation caused her, and stressing that her warning was timely.
He concludes that no opportunity must be lost, and they must be prepared to act immediately upon the ship's arrival in Varna.

events.text_segment:
6 October, morning.—Another surprise. Mina woke me early, about the same time as yesterday, and asked me to bring Dr. Van Helsing. I thought that it was another occasion for hypnotism, and without question went for the Professor. He had evidently expected some such call, for I found him dressed in his room. His door was ajar, so that he could hear the opening of the door of our room. He came at once; as he passed into the room, he asked Mina if the others might come, too.
“No,” she said quite simply, “it will not be necessary. You can tell them just as well. I must go with you on your journey.”
Dr. Van Helsing was as startled as I was. After a moment’s pause he asked:—
“But why?”
“You must take me with you. I am safer with you, and you shall be safer, too.”
“But why, dear Madam Mina? You know that your safety is our solemnest duty. We go into danger, to which you are, or may be, more liable than any of us from—from circumstances—things that have been.” He paused, embarrassed.
As she replied, she raised her finger and pointed to her forehead:—
“I know. That is why I must go. I can tell you now, whilst the sun is coming up; I may not be able again. I know that when the Count wills me I must go. I know that if he tells me to come in secret, I must come by wile; by any device to hoodwink—even Jonathan.” God saw the look that she turned on me as she spoke, and if there be indeed a Recording Angel that look is noted to her everlasting honour. I could only clasp her hand. I could not speak; my emotion was too great for even the relief of tears. She went on:—
“You men are brave and strong. You are strong in your numbers, for you can defy that which would break down the human endurance of one who had to guard alone. Besides, I may be of service, since you can hypnotise me and so learn that which even I myself do not know.” Dr. Van Helsing said very gravely:—
“Madam Mina, you are, as always, most wise. You shall with us come; and together we shall do that which we go forth to achieve.” When he had spoken, Mina’s long spell of silence made me look at her. She had fallen back on her pillow asleep; she did not even wake when I had pulled up the blind and let in the sunlight which flooded the room. Van Helsing motioned to me to come with him quietly. We went to his room, and within a minute Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris were with us also. He told them what Mina had said, and went on:—
“In the morning we shall leave for Varna. We have now to deal with a new factor: Madam Mina. Oh, but her soul is true. It is to her an agony to tell us so much as she has done; but it is most right, and we are warned in time. There must be no chance lost, and in Varna we must be ready to act the instant when that ship arrives.”

events.text_segment:
“What shall we do exactly?” asked Mr. Morris laconically. The Professor paused before replying:—
“We shall at the first board that ship; then, when we have identified the box, we shall place a branch of the wild rose on it. This we shall fasten, for when it is there none can emerge; so at least says the superstition. And to superstition must we trust at the first; it was man’s faith in the early, and it have its root in faith still. Then, when we get the opportunity that we seek, when none are near to see, we shall open the box, and—and all will be well.”
“I shall not wait for any opportunity,” said Morris. “When I see the box I shall open it and destroy the monster, though there were a thousand men looking on, and if I am to be wiped out for it the next moment!” I grasped his hand instinctively and found it as firm as a piece of steel. I think he understood my look; I hope he did.
“Good boy,” said Dr. Van Helsing. “Brave boy. Quincey is all man. God bless him for it. My child, believe me none of us shall lag behind or pause from any fear. I do but say what we may do—what we must do. But, indeed, indeed we cannot say what we shall do. There are so many things which may happen, and their ways and their ends are so various that until the moment we may not say. We shall all be armed, in all ways; and when the time for the end has come, our effort shall not be lack. Now let us to-day put all our affairs in order. Let all things which touch on others dear to us, and who on us depend, be complete; for none of us can tell what, or when, or how, the end may be. As for me, my own affairs are regulate; and as I have nothing else to do, I shall go make arrangements for the travel. I shall have all tickets and so forth for our journey.”
There was nothing further to be said, and we parted. I shall now settle up all my affairs of earth, and be ready for whatever may come....
Later.—It is all done; my will is made, and all complete. Mina if she survive is my sole heir. If it should not be so, then the others who have been so good to us shall have remainder.
It is now drawing towards the sunset; Mina’s uneasiness calls my attention to it. I am sure that there is something on her mind which the time of exact sunset will reveal. These occasions are becoming harrowing times for us all, for each sunrise and sunset opens up some new danger—some new pain, which, however, may in God’s will be means to a good end. I write all these things in the diary since my darling must not hear them now; but if it may be that she can see them again, they shall be ready.
She is calling to me.

events.title: Mina's Desperate Plea and the Solemn Oath
detailed_summary: Dr. Seward begins to document events at Jonathan Harker's request, noting Mina Harker's periods of clarity around sunrise and sunset.

events.text_segment:
11 October, Evening.—Jonathan Harker has asked me to note this, as he says he is hardly equal to the task, and he wants an exact record kept.
I think that none of us were surprised when we were asked to see Mrs. Harker a little before the time of sunset. We have of late come to understand that sunrise and sunset are to her times of peculiar freedom; when her old self can be manifest without any controlling force subduing or restraining her, or inciting her to action. This mood or condition begins some half hour or more before actual sunrise or sunset, and lasts till either the sun is high, or whilst the clouds are still aglow with the rays streaming above the horizon. At first there is a sort of negative condition, as if some tie were loosened, and then the absolute freedom quickly follows; when, however, the freedom ceases the change-back or relapse comes quickly, preceded only by a spell of warning silence.
To-night, when we met, she was somewhat constrained, and bore all the signs of an internal struggle. I put it down myself to her making a violent effort at the earliest instant she could do so. A very few minutes, however, gave her complete control of herself; then, motioning her husband to sit beside her on the sofa where she was half reclining, she made the rest of us bring chairs up close. Taking her husband’s hand in hers began:—
“We are all here together in freedom, for perhaps the last time! I know, dear; I know that you will always be with me to the end.” This was to her husband whose hand had, as we could see, tightened upon hers. “In the morning we go out upon our task, and God alone knows what may be in store for any of us. You are going to be so good to me as to take me with you. I know that all that brave earnest men can do for a poor weak woman, whose soul perhaps is lost—no, no, not yet, but is at any rate at stake—you will do. But you must remember that I am not as you are. There is a poison in my blood, in my soul, which may destroy me; which must destroy me, unless some relief comes to us. Oh, my friends, you know as well as I do, that my soul is at stake; and though I know there is one way out for me, you must not and I must not take it!” She looked appealingly to us all in turn, beginning and ending with her husband.
“What is that way?” asked Van Helsing in a hoarse voice. “What is that way, which we must not—may not—take?”
“That I may die now, either by my own hand or that of another, before the greater evil is entirely wrought. I know, and you know, that were I once dead you could and would set free my immortal spirit, even as you did my poor Lucy’s. Were death, or the fear of death, the only thing that stood in the way I would not shrink to die here, now, amidst the friends who love me. But death is not all. I cannot believe that to die in such a case, when there is hope before us and a bitter task to be done, is God’s will. Therefore, I, on my part, give up here the certainty of eternal rest, and go out into the dark where may be the blackest things that the world or the nether world holds!” We were all silent, for we knew instinctively that this was only a prelude. The faces of the others were set and Harker’s grew ashen grey; perhaps he guessed better than any of us what was coming. She continued:—
“This is what I can give into the hotch-pot.” I could not but note the quaint legal phrase which she used in such a place, and with all seriousness. “What will each of you give? Your lives I know,” she went on quickly, “that is easy for brave men. Your lives are God’s, and you can give them back to Him; but what will you give to me?” She looked again questioningly, but this time avoided her husband’s face. Quincey seemed to understand; he nodded, and her face lit up. “Then I shall tell you plainly what I want, for there must be no doubtful matter in this connection between us now. You must promise me, one and all—even you, my beloved husband—that, should the time come, you will kill me.”
“What is that time?” The voice was Quincey’s, but it was low and strained.
“When you shall be convinced that I am so changed that it is better that I die than I may live. When I am thus dead in the flesh, then you will, without a moment’s delay, drive a stake through me and cut off my head; or do whatever else may be wanting to give me rest!”
Quincey was the first to rise after the pause. He knelt down before her and taking her hand in his said solemnly:—
“I’m only a rough fellow, who hasn’t, perhaps, lived as a man should to win such a distinction, but I swear to you by all that I hold sacred and dear that, should the time ever come, I shall not flinch from the duty that you have set us. And I promise you, too, that I shall make all certain, for if I am only doubtful I shall take it that the time has come!”
“My true friend!” was all she could say amid her fast-falling tears, as, bending over, she kissed his hand.
“I swear the same, my dear Madam Mina!” said Van Helsing.
“And I!” said Lord Godalming, each of them in turn kneeling to her to take the oath. I followed, myself. Then her husband turned to her wan-eyed and with a greenish pallor which subdued the snowy whiteness of his hair, and asked:—
“And must I, too, make such a promise, oh, my wife?”
“You too, my dearest,” she said, with infinite yearning of pity in her voice and eyes. “You must not shrink. You are nearest and dearest and all the world to me; our souls are knit into one, for all life and all time. Think, dear, that there have been times when brave men have killed their wives and their womenkind, to keep them from falling into the hands of the enemy. Their hands did not falter any the more because those that they loved implored them to slay them. It is men’s duty towards those whom they love, in such times of sore trial! And oh, my dear, if it is to be that I must meet death at any hand, let it be at the hand of him that loves me best. Dr. Van Helsing, I have not forgotten your mercy in poor Lucy’s case to him who loved”—she stopped with a flying blush, and changed her phrase—“to him who had best right to give her peace. If that time shall come again, I look to you to make it a happy memory of my husband’s life that it was his loving hand which set me free from the awful thrall upon me.”
“Again I swear!” came the Professor’s resonant voice.

Initially, it feels as if something holding her back is released, followed by complete freedom, but once it ends, she quickly returns to her previous state, usually after a short, solemn silence.

Tonight, when we saw her, she seemed tense and was clearly struggling inside. I thought she was fighting hard to become herself again as soon as it was possible. After a few minutes, she regained control, gestured for her husband to sit next to her, and called the rest of us close. Holding her husband’s hand, she began, “We are together, free, maybe for the last time. My dear, I know you will stay by me to the end.” She looked at her husband, who responded by holding her hand tighter. “Tomorrow, we face our task, and only God knows what will happen. You are kind enough to let me come along. I know you all will do everything you can for me, a weak woman who fears her soul is lost—but not yet, though it is in danger. But remember, I’m not like you. There’s something dark inside me that will destroy me unless we find salvation. You know my soul is at risk; though I know there is a way out, we cannot choose it.” She looked to each of us, starting and ending with her husband.

Van Helsing asked, “What is that way we cannot choose?”

She replied, “That I die now, by my own or another’s hand, before the evil can be completed. If I died, you could free my soul, as you did for Lucy. If death was all, I would not hesitate to die here among my friends. But it’s not simply about death. If there’s hope and a difficult task ahead, I cannot believe dying now is God’s will. So I give up the certainty of peace for the unknown, facing whatever darkness may come.” We all stayed silent, knowing more was to come. The others’ faces were set, and Harker went pale; perhaps he understood best what was coming next. She continued: “Here is my contribution.” I noticed her use of a legal term, even in this serious moment. “What will each of you give? Your lives, I know, for you are brave men—but what will you give for me?” She looked at us again, avoiding her husband’s gaze. Quincey nodded, and she seemed encouraged. “I must be direct. All of you, including my husband, must promise that if the time comes, you will kill me.”

Quincey, his voice strained, asked, “When is that time?”

“When you’re convinced I’ve changed so much that it would be better for me to die than keep living. When I am truly dead, without delay, you must stake me and cut off my head—or do whatever is needed to give me peace.”

After a pause, Quincey knelt before her, took her hand, and said solemnly, “I’m not a refined man, but I swear by all I hold dear that if that time comes, I won’t hesitate to do what you ask. And I’ll make sure of it, even if I have doubts.” She could only thank him through tears and kissed his hand.

“I swear the same, Madam Mina,” said Van Helsing, followed by Lord Godalming, each also kneeling and swearing the oath. I did so too. Then Jonathan, pale and shaken, asked, “Must I make such a promise, too, my wife?”

With deep love and pity, she replied, “Yes, my dearest. Do not hesitate. You are closest to me; our souls are joined for all time. Remember, sometimes, men have had to kill the women they loved to keep them from the enemy. They did not fail, even when their loved ones begged for mercy. This is what a man must do for those he loves in such hard times. And if I must die, let it be by your hand, who loves me most. Dr. Van Helsing, I remember your kindness to poor Lucy’s lover—you let him do what was needed for her. If the time comes again, I hope my husband will have that same memory: that it was his loving hand that set me free from this terrible fate.”

“I swear it again!” Van Helsing answered boldly.

events.title: Mina's Warnings, Final Request, and a Somber Ritual
detailed_summary: Mina, relieved by their promises, issues a critical warning: her transformation might occur suddenly, and if it does, she will become their enemy, urging them to act swiftly without hesitation.

Jonathan is deeply pained by this request, but Mina insists it would comfort her, prompting him to agree.
Jonathan then reads the Burial Service for Mina, a scene described by Seward as profoundly solemn, gloomy, sad, horrific, yet also sweet, capable of melting even a skeptic's heart.
Seward notes that Mina's instinct was correct; the act, though bizarre, brought comfort to them all and lessened the despair of her impending relapse from mental freedom.

Mrs. Harker smiled, positively smiled, as with a sigh of relief she leaned back and said:—
“And now one word of warning, a warning which you must never forget: this time, if it ever come, may come quickly and unexpectedly, and in such case you must lose no time in using your opportunity. At such a time I myself might be—nay! if the time ever comes, shall be—leagued with your enemy against you.”
“One more request;” she became very solemn as she said this, “it is not vital and necessary like the other, but I want you to do one thing for me, if you will.” We all acquiesced, but no one spoke; there was no need to speak:—
“I want you to read the Burial Service.” She was interrupted by a deep groan from her husband; taking his hand in hers, she held it over her heart, and continued: “You must read it over me some day. Whatever may be the issue of all this fearful state of things, it will be a sweet thought to all or some of us. You, my dearest, will I hope read it, for then it will be in your voice in my memory for ever—come what may!”
“But oh, my dear one,” he pleaded, “death is afar off from you.”
“Nay,” she said, holding up a warning hand. “I am deeper in death at this moment than if the weight of an earthly grave lay heavy upon me!”
“Oh, my wife, must I read it?” he said, before he began.
“It would comfort me, my husband!” was all she said; and he began to read when she had got the book ready.
“How can I—how could any one—tell of that strange scene, its solemnity, its gloom, its sadness, its horror; and, withal, its sweetness. events.text_segment:
Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
15 October, Varna.—We left Charing Cross on the morning of the 12th, got to Paris the same night, and took the places secured for us in the Orient Express. We travelled night and day, arriving here at about five o’clock. Lord Godalming went to the Consulate to see if any telegram had arrived for him, whilst the rest of us came on to this hotel—“the Odessus.” The journey may have had incidents; I was, however, too eager to get on, to care for them. Until the Czarina Catherine comes into port there will be no interest for me in anything in the wide world. Thank God! Mina is well, and looks to be getting stronger; her colour is coming back. She sleeps a great deal; throughout the journey she slept nearly all the time. Before sunrise and sunset, however, she is very wakeful and alert; and it has become a habit for Van Helsing to hypnotise her at such times. At first, some effort was needed, and he had to make many passes; but now, she seems to yield at once, as if by habit, and scarcely any action is needed. He seems to have power at these particular moments to simply will, and her thoughts obey him. He always asks her what she can see and hear. She answers to the first:—
“Nothing; all is dark.” And to the second:—
“I can hear the waves lapping against the ship, and the water rushing by. Canvas and cordage strain and masts and yards creak. The wind is high—I can hear it in the shrouds, and the bow throws back the foam.” It is evident that the Czarina Catherine is still at sea, hastening on her way to Varna. Lord Godalming has just returned. He had four telegrams, one each day since we started, and all to the same effect: that the Czarina Catherine had not been reported to Lloyd’s from anywhere. He had arranged before leaving London that his agent should send him every day a telegram saying if the ship had been reported. He was to have a message even if she were not reported, so that he might be sure that there was a watch being kept at the other end of the wire.
We had dinner and went to bed early. To-morrow we are to see the Vice-Consul, and to arrange, if we can, about getting on board the ship as soon as she arrives. Van Helsing says that our chance will be to get on the boat between sunrise and sunset. The Count, even if he takes the form of a bat, cannot cross the running water of his own volition, and so cannot leave the ship. As he dare not change to man’s form without suspicion—which he evidently wishes to avoid—he must remain in the box. If, then, we can come on board after sunrise, he is at our mercy; for we can open the box and make sure of him, as we did of poor Lucy, before he wakes. What mercy he shall get from us will not count for much. We think that we shall not have much trouble with officials or the seamen. Thank God! this is the country where bribery can do anything, and we are well supplied with money. We have only to make sure that the ship cannot come into port between sunset and sunrise without our being warned, and we shall be safe. Judge Moneybag will settle this case, I think!
16 October.—Mina’s report still the same: lapping waves and rushing water, darkness and favouring winds. We are evidently in good time, and when we hear of the Czarina Catherine we shall be ready. As she must pass the Dardanelles we are sure to have some report.
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
17 October.—Everything is pretty well fixed now, I think, to welcome the Count on his return from his tour. Godalming told the shippers that he fancied that the box sent aboard might contain something stolen from a friend of his, and got a half consent that he might open it at his own risk. The owner gave him a paper telling the Captain to give him every facility in doing whatever he chose on board the ship, and also a similar authorisation to his agent at Varna. We have seen the agent, who was much impressed with Godalming’s kindly manner to him, and we are all satisfied that whatever he can do to aid our wishes will be done. We have already arranged what to do in case we get the box open. If the Count is there, Van Helsing and Seward will cut off his head at once and drive a stake through his heart. Morris and Godalming and I shall prevent interference, even if we have to use the arms which we shall have ready. The Professor says that if we can so treat the Count’s body, it will soon after fall into dust. In such case there would be no evidence against us, in case any suspicion of murder were aroused. But even if it were not, we should stand or fall by our act, and perhaps some day this very script may be evidence to come between some of us and a rope. For myself, I should take the chance only too thankfully if it were to come. We mean to leave no stone unturned to carry out our intent. We have arranged with certain officials that the instant the Czarina Catherine is seen, we are to be informed by a special messenger.

events.text_segment:
24 October.—A whole week of waiting. Daily telegrams to Godalming, but only the same story: “Not yet reported.” Mina’s morning and evening hypnotic answer is unvaried: lapping waves, rushing water, and creaking masts.
Telegram, October 24th.
Rufus Smith, Lloyd’s, London, to Lord Godalming, care of H. B. M.
Vice-Consul, Varna.
“Czarina Catherine reported this morning from Dardanelles.”
Dr. Seward’s Diary.
25 October.—How I miss my phonograph! To write diary with a pen is irksome to me; but Van Helsing says I must. We were all wild with excitement yesterday when Godalming got his telegram from Lloyd’s. I know now what men feel in battle when the call to action is heard. Mrs. Harker, alone of our party, did not show any signs of emotion. After all, it is not strange that she did not; for we took special care not to let her know anything about it, and we all tried not to show any excitement when we were in her presence. In old days she would, I am sure, have noticed, no matter how we might have tried to conceal it; but in this way she is greatly changed during the past three weeks. The lethargy grows upon her, and though she seems strong and well, and is getting back some of her colour, Van Helsing and I are not satisfied. We talk of her often; we have not, however, said a word to the others. It would break poor Harker’s heart—certainly his nerve—if he knew that we had even a suspicion on the subject. Van Helsing examines, he tells me, her teeth very carefully, whilst she is in the hypnotic condition, for he says that so long as they do not begin to sharpen there is no active danger of a change in her. If this change should come, it would be necessary to take steps!... We both know what those steps would have to be, though we do not mention our thoughts to each other. We should neither of us shrink from the task—awful though it be to contemplate. “Euthanasia” is an excellent and a comforting word! I am grateful to whoever invented it.
It is only about 24 hours’ sail from the Dardanelles to here, at the rate the Czarina Catherine has come from London. She should therefore arrive some time in the morning; but as she cannot possibly get in before then, we are all about to retire early. We shall get up at one o’clock, so as to be ready.
25 October, Noon.—No news yet of the ship’s arrival. Mrs. Harker’s hypnotic report this morning was the same as usual, so it is possible that we may get news at any moment. We men are all in a fever of excitement, except Harker, who is calm; his hands are cold as ice, and an hour ago I found him whetting the edge of the great Ghoorka knife which he now always carries with him. It will be a bad lookout for the Count if the edge of that “Kukri” ever touches his throat, driven by that stern, ice-cold hand!
Van Helsing and I were a little alarmed about Mrs. Harker to-day. About noon she got into a sort of lethargy which we did not like; although we kept silence to the others, we were neither of us happy about it. She had been restless all the morning, so that we were at first glad to know that she was sleeping. When, however, her husband mentioned casually that she was sleeping so soundly that he could not wake her, we went to her room to see for ourselves. She was breathing naturally and looked so well and peaceful that we agreed that the sleep was better for her than anything else. Poor girl, she has so much to forget that it is no wonder that sleep, if it brings oblivion to her, does her good.
Later.—Our opinion was justified, for when after a refreshing sleep of some hours she woke up, she seemed brighter and better than she had been for days. At sunset she made the usual hypnotic report. Wherever he may be in the Black Sea, the Count is hurrying to his destination. To his doom, I trust!
26 October.—Another day and no tidings of the Czarina Catherine. She ought to be here by now. That she is still journeying somewhere is apparent, for Mrs. Harker’s hypnotic report at sunrise was still the same. It is possible that the vessel may be lying by, at times, for fog; some of the steamers which came in last evening reported patches of fog both to north and south of the port. We must continue our watching, as the ship may now be signalled any moment.
27 October, Noon.—Most strange; no news yet of the ship we wait for. Mrs. Harker reported last night and this morning as usual: “lapping waves and rushing water,” though she added that “the waves were very faint.” The telegrams from London have been the same: “no further report.” Van Helsing is terribly anxious, and told me just now that he fears the Count is escaping us. He added significantly:—
“I did not like that lethargy of Madam Mina’s. Souls and memories can do strange things during trance.” I was about to ask him more, but Harker just then came in, and he held up a warning hand. We must try to-night at sunset to make her speak more fully when in her hypnotic state.

“The ship Czarina Catherine has been reported from the Dardanelles this morning.”

I truly miss using my phonograph! Writing this diary with a pen feels cumbersome, but Van Helsing insists I must. The news yesterday, when Godalming received the telegram from Lloyd’s, sent us all into a frenzy of excitement. I now understand the feeling men experience in battle upon hearing the call to fight. Of our group, only Mrs. Harker showed no outward sign of emotion. This isn't surprising, as we were careful to keep the information from her and controlled our own reactions in her presence. In the past, I am certain she would have noticed our efforts to hide something, no matter how hard we tried; however, she has changed significantly in this regard over the last three weeks. A growing lethargy seems to affect her, and despite appearing physically strong and regaining some colour, Van Helsing and I are concerned. We discuss her condition frequently but have not mentioned our worries to the others. Revealing our suspicions on this matter would undoubtedly devastate poor Harker, shattering his composure. Van Helsing informs me that he meticulously examines her teeth while she is under hypnosis. He believes that as long as they haven't begun to sharpen, there is no immediate threat of transformation. Should this change occur, decisive action would be required!... We both understand what those necessary steps would entail, though we refrain from articulating these thoughts to one another. Neither of us would flinch from the task, as dreadful as it is to contemplate. The word “Euthanasia” is truly excellent and comforting! I am thankful to whoever coined it.
Given the speed the Czarina Catherine travelled from London, it should take only about 24 hours to sail from the Dardanelles to our location. Therefore, its arrival is expected sometime in the morning. As it cannot possibly reach port before then, we are all planning to retire early. We will wake up at one o'clock to be ready.
October 25th, Noon:
Still no news of the ship’s arrival. Mrs. Harker’s hypnotic account this morning was unchanged from previous ones, suggesting that we could receive news at any moment. We men are all quite tense with anticipation, except for Harker, who remains outwardly calm. His hands are incredibly cold, and about an hour ago, I observed him sharpening the large Gurkha knife he now constantly carries. It will be a grim prospect for the Count if that 'Kukri's' blade is ever driven into his throat by Harker's determined, icy hand!
Today, Van Helsing and I felt some concern regarding Mrs. Harker. Around midday, she fell into a state of listlessness that we found unsettling. Although we didn't voice our worries to the others, neither of us was comfortable. She had been restless earlier in the morning, so her sleeping initially seemed welcome. However, when her husband casually mentioned that her sleep was so deep he couldn't wake her, we went to her room to check. She was breathing normally and appeared so restful and serene that we concluded sleep was the best thing for her. The poor girl has so much she needs to forget; it’s understandable that sleep, if it brings her oblivion, would be beneficial.
Later:
Our earlier assessment proved correct, as she woke up after several hours of refreshing sleep looking brighter and more improved than she had in days. At sunset, she provided her usual hypnotic report. Wherever the Count might be in the Black Sea, he is clearly accelerating towards his destination. Towards his destruction, I hope!
October 26th:
Another day has passed with no word of the Czarina Catherine. She should have arrived by now. Her continued journey is evident from Mrs. Harker’s hypnotic report at sunrise, which remained the same. It's possible the vessel is experiencing delays due to fog; some steamers that arrived last evening reported patches of fog both north and south of the harbour. We must keep vigil, as the ship could be sighted at any moment now.
October 27th, Noon:
This is most peculiar; there is still no news of the ship we are awaiting. Mrs. Harker’s reports last night and this morning were consistent with the usual description of “lapping waves and rushing water,” although she did mention that “the waves were very faint.” The telegrams from London have also been unchanged: “no further report.” Van Helsing is extremely worried and just told me he fears the Count is getting away from us. He added pointedly:
“I was troubled by Madam Mina’s lethargy. Souls and memories are capable of strange things during a trance state.” I was about to ask him more, but Harker entered the room just then, and Van Helsing raised a hand as a warning signal. We must try to encourage her to provide more detail during her hypnotic state at sunset tonight.

events.title: Unexpected Diversion to Galatz and Rapid Re-planning
detailed_summary: A telegram on October 28th announces that the Czarina Catherine has been reported entering Galatz, not Varna.
Dr. Seward notes that while the news was a surprise, the preceding delays had led them to expect a deviation from their plans.

The group reacts variously to the news: Van Helsing raises his hand as if in remonstrance, Godalming pales, Seward is stunned, Morris instinctively prepares for action, Mina turns white but prays, and Harker smiles bitterly while gripping his Kukri knife.
Mina unexpectedly provides crucial information: she knows the train schedule to Galatz, having studied timetables in anticipation of a journey towards Castle Dracula.

Van Helsing quickly devises a new plan: Arthur (Lord Godalming) will secure train tickets; Jonathan will obtain letters of authorization for Galatz; Quincey will seek aid from the Vice-Consul for their passage over the Danube.
Seward is to stay with Mina and Van Helsing for consultation.
Mina, feeling strangely freer and more like her old self, offers to assist with thinking and writing, which brings a moment of happiness to the younger men.
However, Van Helsing and Seward exchange grave, troubled glances, sensing something amiss despite Mina's apparent improvement.

events.text_segment:
28 October.—Telegram. Rufus Smith, London, to Lord Godalming, care H. B. M. Vice Consul, Varna.
“Czarina Catherine reported entering Galatz at one o’clock to-day.”
Dr. Seward’s Diary.
28 October.—When the telegram came announcing the arrival in Galatz I do not think it was such a shock to any of us as might have been expected. True, we did not know whence, or how, or when, the bolt would come; but I think we all expected that something strange would happen. The delay of arrival at Varna made us individually satisfied that things would not be just as we had expected; we only waited to learn where the change would occur. None the less, however, was it a surprise. I suppose that nature works on such a hopeful basis that we believe against ourselves that things will be as they ought to be, not as we should know that they will be. Transcendentalism is a beacon to the angels, even if it be a will-o’-the-wisp to man. It was an odd experience and we all took it differently. Van Helsing raised his hand over his head for a moment, as though in remonstrance with the Almighty; but he said not a word, and in a few seconds stood up with his face sternly set. Lord Godalming grew very pale, and sat breathing heavily. I was myself half stunned and looked in wonder at one after another. Quincey Morris tightened his belt with that quick movement which I knew so well; in our old wandering days it meant “action.” Mrs. Harker grew ghastly white, so that the scar on her forehead seemed to burn, but she folded her hands meekly and looked up in prayer. Harker smiled—actually smiled—the dark, bitter smile of one who is without hope; but at the same time his action belied his words, for his hands instinctively sought the hilt of the great Kukri knife and rested there. “When does the next train start for Galatz?” said Van Helsing to us generally.
“At 6:30 to-morrow morning!” We all started, for the answer came from Mrs. Harker.
“How on earth do you know?” said Art.
“You forget—or perhaps you do not know, though Jonathan does and so does Dr. Van Helsing—that I am the train fiend. At home in Exeter I always used to make up the time-tables, so as to be helpful to my husband. I found it so useful sometimes, that I always make a study of the time-tables now. I knew that if anything were to take us to Castle Dracula we should go by Galatz, or at any rate through Bucharest, so I learned the times very carefully. Unhappily there are not many to learn, as the only train to-morrow leaves as I say.”
“Wonderful woman!” murmured the Professor.
“Can’t we get a special?” asked Lord Godalming. Van Helsing shook his head: “I fear not. This land is very different from yours or mine; even if we did have a special, it would probably not arrive as soon as our regular train. Moreover, we have something to prepare. We must think. Now let us organize. You, friend Arthur, go to the train and get the tickets and arrange that all be ready for us to go in the morning. Do you, friend Jonathan, go to the agent of the ship and get from him letters to the agent in Galatz, with authority to make search the ship just as it was here. Morris Quincey, you see the Vice-Consul, and get his aid with his fellow in Galatz and all he can do to make our way smooth, so that no times be lost when over the Danube. John will stay with Madam Mina and me, and we shall consult. For so if time be long you may be delayed; and it will not matter when the sun set, since I am here with Madam to make report.”
“And I,” said Mrs. Harker brightly, and more like her old self than she had been for many a long day, “shall try to be of use in all ways, and shall think and write for you as I used to do. Something is shifting from me in some strange way, and I feel freer than I have been of late!” The three younger men looked happier at the moment as they seemed to realise the significance of her words; but Van Helsing and I, turning to each other, met each a grave and troubled glance. We said nothing at the time, however.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
October 28th – A telegram was received. It was from Rufus Smith in London, addressed to Lord Godalming, who was staying with the British Vice Consul in Varna. The message reported that the ship 'Czarina Catherine' was said to have arrived in Galatz earlier that day, at one o'clock.

Dr. Seward's Diary.

October 28th – When the telegram arrived announcing the ship's arrival in Galatz, I don't believe it startled us as much as it might have. Although we didn't know the exact nature, timing, or origin of the impending danger, I think we all anticipated something unusual would occur. The delay in the ship reaching Varna had already convinced us individually that events wouldn't unfold exactly as planned; we were simply waiting to discover where the change would manifest. Nevertheless, it was still a shock. I suppose it's human nature to hold onto hope, even against our better judgment, believing things will turn out as they should, not as our experience suggests they will. Such idealism might guide angels, even if it deceives humans. It was a strange moment, and each of us reacted differently. Van Helsing momentarily raised his hand above his head, seemingly in protest to the heavens, but spoke no word. Within seconds, he stood up, his face set in grim determination. Lord Godalming turned very pale and breathed heavily. I felt half-stupefied myself, staring in wonder at each person in turn. Quincey Morris gave a quick tug to his belt, a familiar gesture from our adventurous past that always signaled readiness for 'action'. Mrs. Harker became deathly white, her forehead scar appearing to intensify, yet she calmly clasped her hands and looked upwards in prayer. Harker smiled—yes, actually smiled—a dark, bitter smile like someone who has lost all hope, but his actions contradicted this, as his hands instinctively went to the handle of his large Kukri knife and rested there. Van Helsing then addressed the group, asking, "When is the next train for Galatz?"

To our surprise, the answer came from Mrs. Harker: "At 6:30 tomorrow morning!" We all started, taken aback.

Art asked, "How on earth do you know?"

She replied, "You forget – or perhaps you don't know, though Jonathan and Dr. Van Helsing do – that I'm a bit of a train enthusiast. When I was at home in Exeter, I always made a habit of studying the train timetables to help my husband. I found it so useful sometimes that I continue to study timetables now. I knew that if we needed to travel towards Castle Dracula, we would likely go via Galatz, or at least through Bucharest, so I memorized the schedules carefully. Unfortunately, there aren't many options; the only train tomorrow departs at the time I mentioned."

"Remarkable woman!" the Professor murmured.

"Can't we get a special train?" Lord Godalming inquired. Van Helsing shook his head. "I doubt it. This country is quite unlike yours or mine; even if we could arrange a special, it likely wouldn't arrive any sooner than our scheduled train. Furthermore, we need time to prepare and strategize. Now, let's organize. Arthur, my friend, you go to the station, purchase the tickets, and ensure everything is arranged for our departure in the morning. Jonathan, you go to the ship's agent and obtain letters for the agent in Galatz, granting us permission to search the ship there, just as it was examined here. Morris Quincey, you will see the Vice-Consul and enlist his aid, both with his colleague in Galatz and with anything else he can do to facilitate our journey, so no time is wasted crossing the Danube. John will remain here with Madam Mina and myself, and we will strategize. This way, even if you are delayed, it won't matter when the sun sets, as I will be here with Madam to make a report."

Mrs. Harker spoke up cheerfully, sounding more like her usual self than she had in a long time. "And I," she said, "shall try to be helpful in every way, and will think and write for you, just as I used to. Something is shifting within me in a strange manner, and I feel freer than I have recently!" The three younger men looked happier at that moment, as they seemed to grasp the significance of her words. However, Van Helsing and I exchanged glances and met each other's serious and troubled expressions. We did not say anything further at that time.

When the three men had gone out to their tasks Van Helsing asked Mrs. Harker to look up the copy of the diaries and find him the part of Harker’s journal at the Castle. She went away to get it; when the door was shut upon her he said to me:—
“We mean the same! speak out!”
“There is some change. It is a hope that makes me sick, for it may deceive us.”
“Quite so. Do you know why I asked her to get the manuscript?”
“No!” said I, “unless it was to get an opportunity of seeing me alone.”
“You are in part right, friend John, but only in part. I want to tell you something. And oh, my friend, I am taking a great—a terrible—risk; but I believe it is right. In the moment when Madam Mina said those words that arrest both our understanding, an inspiration came to me. In the trance of three days ago the Count sent her his spirit to read her mind; or more like he took her to see him in his earth-box in the ship with water rushing, just as it go free at rise and set of sun. He learn then that we are here; for she have more to tell in her open life with eyes to see and ears to hear than he, shut, as he is, in his coffin-box. Now he make his most effort to escape us. At present he want her not.
“He is sure with his so great knowledge that she will come at his call; but he cut her off—take her, as he can do, out of his own power, that so she come not to him. Ah! there I have hope that our man-brains that have been of man so long and that have not lost the grace of God, will come higher than his child-brain that lie in his tomb for centuries, that grow not yet to our stature, and that do only work selfish and therefore small. Here comes Madam Mina; not a word to her of her trance! She know it not; and it would overwhelm her and make despair just when we want all her hope, all her courage; when most we want all her great brain which is trained like man’s brain, but is of sweet woman and have a special power which the Count give her, and which he may not take away altogether—though he think not so. Hush! let me speak, and you shall learn. Oh, John, my friend, we are in awful straits. I fear, as I never feared before. We can only trust the good God. Silence! here she comes!”

events.text_segment:
I thought that the Professor was going to break down and have hysterics, just as he had when Lucy died, but with a great effort he controlled himself and was at perfect nervous poise when Mrs. Harker tripped into the room, bright and happy-looking and, in the doing of work, seemingly forgetful of her misery. As she came in, she handed a number of sheets of typewriting to Van Helsing. He looked over them gravely, his face brightening up as he read. Then holding the pages between his finger and thumb he said:—
“Friend John, to you with so much of experience already—and you, too, dear Madam Mina, that are young—here is a lesson: do not fear ever to think. A half-thought has been buzzing often in my brain, but I fear to let him loose his wings. Here now, with more knowledge, I go back to where that half-thought come from and I find that he be no half-thought at all; that be a whole thought, though so young that he is not yet strong to use his little wings. Nay, like the “Ugly Duck” of my friend Hans Andersen, he be no duck-thought at all, but a big swan-thought that sail nobly on big wings, when the time come for him to try them. See I read here what Jonathan have written:—
“That other of his race who, in a later age, again and again, brought his forces over The Great River into Turkey Land; who, when he was beaten back, came again, and again, and again, though he had to come alone from the bloody field where his troops were being slaughtered, since he knew that he alone could ultimately triumph.”
“What does this tell us? Not much? no! The Count’s child-thought see nothing; therefore he speak so free. Your man-thought see nothing; my man-thought see nothing, till just now. No! But there comes another word from some one who speak without thought because she, too, know not what it mean—what it might mean. Just as there are elements which rest, yet when in nature’s course they move on their way and they touch—then pouf! and there comes a flash of light, heaven wide, that blind and kill and destroy some; but that show up all earth below for leagues and leagues. Is it not so? Well, I shall explain. To begin, have you ever study the philosophy of crime? ‘Yes’ and ‘No.’ You, John, yes; for it is a study of insanity. You, no, Madam Mina; for crime touch you not—not but once. Still, your mind works true, and argues not a particulari ad universale. There is this peculiarity in criminals. It is so constant, in all countries and at all times, that even police, who know not much from philosophy, come to know it empirically, that it is. That is to be empiric. The criminal always work at one crime—that is the true criminal who seems predestinate to crime, and who will of none other. This criminal has not full man-brain. He is clever and cunning and resourceful; but he be not of man-stature as to brain. He be of child-brain in much. Now this criminal of ours is predestinate to crime also; he, too, have child-brain, and it is of the child to do what he have done. The little bird, the little fish, the little animal learn not by principle, but empirically; and when he learn to do, then there is to him the ground to start from to do more. ‘Dos pou sto,’ said Archimedes. ‘Give me a fulcrum, and I shall move the world!’ To do once, is the fulcrum whereby child-brain become man-brain; and until he have the purpose to do more, he continue to do the same again every time, just as he have done before! Oh, my dear, I see that your eyes are opened, and that to you the lightning flash show all the leagues,” for Mrs. Harker began to clap her hands and her eyes sparkled. He went on:—
“Now you shall speak. Tell us two dry men of science what you see with those so bright eyes.” He took her hand and held it whilst she spoke. His finger and thumb closed on her pulse, as I thought instinctively and unconsciously, as she spoke:—
“The Count is a criminal and of criminal type. Nordau and Lombroso would so classify him, and quâ criminal he is of imperfectly formed mind. Thus, in a difficulty he has to seek resource in habit. His past is a clue, and the one page of it that we know—and that from his own lips—tells that once before, when in what Mr. Morris would call a ‘tight place,’ he went back to his own country from the land he had tried to invade, and thence, without losing purpose, prepared himself for a new effort. He came again better equipped for his work; and won. So he came to London to invade a new land. He was beaten, and when all hope of success was lost, and his existence in danger, he fled back over the sea to his home; just as formerly he had fled back over the Danube from Turkey Land.”
“Good, good! oh, you so clever lady!” said Van Helsing, enthusiastically, as he stooped and kissed her hand. A moment later he said to me, as calmly as though we had been having a sick-room consultation:—
“Seventy-two only; and in all this excitement. I have hope.” Turning to her again, he said with keen expectation:—
“But go on. Go on! there is more to tell if you will. Be not afraid; John and I know. I do in any case, and shall tell you if you are right. Speak, without fear!”
“I will try to; but you will forgive me if I seem egotistical.”
“Nay! fear not, you must be egotist, for it is of you that we think.”
“Then, as he is criminal he is selfish; and as his intellect is small and his action is based on selfishness, he confines himself to one purpose. That purpose is remorseless. As he fled back over the Danube, leaving his forces to be cut to pieces, so now he is intent on being safe, careless of all. So his own selfishness frees my soul somewhat from the terrible power which he acquired over me on that dreadful night. I felt it! Oh, I felt it! Thank God, for His great mercy! My soul is freer than it has been since that awful hour; and all that haunts me is a fear lest in some trance or dream he may have used my knowledge for his ends.” The Professor stood up:—
“He has so used your mind; and by it he has left us here in Varna, whilst the ship that carried him rushed through enveloping fog up to Galatz, where, doubtless, he had made preparation for escaping from us. But his child-mind only saw so far; and it may be that, as ever is in God’s Providence, the very thing that the evil-doer most reckoned on for his selfish good, turns out to be his chiefest harm. The hunter is taken in his own snare, as the great Psalmist says. For now that he think he is free from every trace of us all, and that he has escaped us with so many hours to him, then his selfish child-brain will whisper him to sleep. He think, too, that as he cut himself off from knowing your mind, there can be no knowledge of him to you; there is where he fail! That terrible baptism of blood which he give you makes you free to go to him in spirit, as you have as yet done in your times of freedom, when the sun rise and set. At such times you go by my volition and not by his; and this power to good of you and others, as you have won from your suffering at his hands. This is now all the more precious that he know it not, and to guard himself have even cut himself off from his knowledge of our where. We, however, are not selfish, and we believe that God is with us through all this blackness, and these many dark hours. We shall follow him; and we shall not flinch; even if we peril ourselves that we become like him. Friend John, this has been a great hour; and it have done much to advance us on our way. You must be scribe and write him all down, so that when the others return from their work you can give it to them; then they shall know as we do.”
And so I have written it whilst we wait their return, and Mrs. Harker has written with her typewriter all since she brought the MS. to us.
